content: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <?xml-stylesheet type="text/xsl" href="fgdc_classic.xsl"?> <metadata xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://water.usgs.gov/GIS/metadata/usgswrd/fgdc-std-001-1998.xsd">  <idinfo>   <citation>    <citeinfo>     <origin>Donald R Pool</origin>     <origin>Stanley Leake</origin>     <origin>Jesse Dickinson</origin>     <pubdate>2014</pubdate>     <title>Digital geospatial dataset of the top of Paleozoic rocks in the Upper Colorado River Basin</title>     <geoform>Raster Digital Data Set</geoform>     <pubinfo>      <pubplace>Reston, Virginia</pubplace>      <publish>U.S. Geological Survey</publish>     </pubinfo>     <onlink>http://water.usgs.gov/lookup/getspatial?ucrb_Paleoz_top</onlink>    </citeinfo>   </citation>   <descript>    <abstract>These raster data of the top surface of the Paleozoic formation of the Upper Colorado River Basin (UCRB) were created for the purpose of developing a generalized predevelopment groundwater flow model of the Mesozoic and Paleozoic aquifers in the Upper Colorado River Basin and use that model along with a few recharge estimates to estimate water budgets for the aquifers including associated groundwater contributions to the Colorado River surface water system. The modeling exercise also explored considerations for development of a more detailed groundwater flow model that would include all of the major aquifers in the Upper Colorado River Basin. </abstract>    <purpose>These data were derived from various other sources (maps) in order to present a cohesive top of the Paleozoic rocks in the Upper Colorado River Basin for use in the development of the Upper Colorado River Basin Groundwater Flow Model.</purpose>    <supplinf>Data are as current as the publications that provided the information and maps.  Depth contours from PP1411-A, Plate 3 (2003), altitude contours of the top of Permian rocks in the San Juan Basin area from Bulletin 1808-O Figure 18 (1993), and from NARGFM top of model layer 1 (top of Kaibab land surface).  The land-surface digital elevation models(DEM) used to derive depths were developed as follows: Land surface in the study area includes DEM in the area of the UCRB  and adjacent areas outside of the UCRB in New Mexico and Arizona.  The areas outside of UCRB were included to account for areas of recharge to Mesozoic and Paleozoic rocks that contribute to UCRB GW budgets and areas of discharge from Paleozoic and Mesozoic rocks to the Colorado and Little Colorado rivers.  1. The UCRB DEM is a 100m grid file \ufffd\ufffd\ufffddem_nad83_utm\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd 2. The source of New Mexico DEM is the NW and SW state quadrant DEMs at 30m resolution. \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdnm_ned09_30m_nw_qtr2\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd and \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdnm_ned09_30m_sw_qtr2\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd 3. The source of northern Arizona DEMs is a 500m DEM derived from 10m DEMs for the NARGFM study area.  4. DEMs were merged using the UCRB DEM as the dominant raster to produce \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdUCRpaleo_LSA\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd for the entire study area including extents of Paleozoic rock that may contribute to UCRB GW flow in AZ and NM. For stream elevation use the DEMs were processed to determine the minimum elevation within each 500-meter cell. \ufffd\ufffd\ufffducrb_500m_minlsa.tif\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd</supplinf>   </descript>   <timeperd>    <timeinfo>     <sngdate>      <caldate>2013</caldate>     </sngdate>    </timeinfo>    <current>See Supplemental Info</current>   </timeperd>   <status>    <progress>Complete</progress>    <update>None planned</update>   </status>   <spdom>    <bounding>     <westbc>-112.452244421</westbc>     <eastbc>-105.333561362</eastbc>     <northbc>43.460904797</northbc>     <southbc>34.374429275</southbc>    </bounding>   </spdom>   <keywords>    <theme>     <themekt>None</themekt>     <themekey>inlandWaters</themekey>     <themekey>Paleozoic rocks</themekey>    </theme>    <place>     <placekt>None</placekt>     <placekey>Colorado</placekey>     <placekey>Arizona</placekey>     <placekey>Utah</placekey>     <placekey>New Mexico</placekey>    </place>   </keywords>   <accconst>None. Please see 'Distribution Info' for details.</accconst>   <useconst>None. Users are advised to read the data set's metadata thoroughly to understand appropriate use and data limitations.</useconst>   <ptcontac>    <cntinfo>     <cntorgp>      <cntorg>U.S. Geological Survey, Southwest Region</cntorg>      <cntper>Donald R Pool</cntper>     </cntorgp>     <cntpos>Hydrologist</cntpos>     <cntaddr>      <addrtype>mailing address</addrtype>      <address>520 North Park Avenue</address>      <city>Tucson</city>      <state>AZ</state>      <postal>85721</postal>     </cntaddr>     <cntvoice>520-670-6671 x258</cntvoice>     <cntfax>520-670-5592</cntfax>     <cntemail>drpool@usgs.gov</cntemail>    </cntinfo>   </ptcontac>   <browse>    <browsen>http://water.usgs.gov/GIS/browse/UCRB_Paleo_top.jpg</browsen>    <browsed>Illustration of the dataset.</browsed>    <browset>JPG</browset>   </browse>   <native>Environment as of Metadata Creation: Microsoft Windows 7 Version 6.1 (Build 7601) Service Pack 1; ESRI ArcCatalog 10.2 (Build 3497) Service Pack [N/A] (Build [N/A])</native>  </idinfo>  <dataqual>   <attracc>    <attraccr>Initial digitizing of maps and figures included a visual check to be sure all linework was present, and all lines were labelled correctly.</attraccr>   </attracc>   <logic>No formal logical accuracy tests were conducted.</logic>   <complete>Data set is considered complete for the information presented. Users are advised to read the rest of the metadata record carefully for additional details.</complete>   <posacc>    <horizpa>     <horizpar>A formal accuracy assessment of the horizontal positional information in the data set has not been conducted.</horizpar>    </horizpa>    <vertacc>     <vertaccr>A formal accuracy assessment of the vertical positional information in the data set has either not been conducted, or is not applicable.</vertaccr>    </vertacc>   </posacc>   <lineage>    <srcinfo>     <srccite>      <citeinfo>       <origin>Geldon, Arthur L.</origin>       <pubdate>2003</pubdate>       <title>Geology of Paleozoic Rocks in the Upper Colorado River Basin in Arizona, Colorado, New Mexico, Utah, and Wyoming, Excluding the San Juan Basin</title>       <geoform>Digital and/or Hardcopy Resources</geoform>       <pubinfo>        <pubplace>Reston, VA</pubplace>        <publish>U.S. Geological Survey</publish>       </pubinfo>       <onlink>http://pubs.usgs.gov/pp/1411a/plate-03.pdf</onlink>      </citeinfo>     </srccite>     <typesrc>Digital and/or Hardcopy Resources</typesrc>     <srctime>      <timeinfo>       <sngdate>        <caldate>2003</caldate>       </sngdate>      </timeinfo>      <srccurr>publication date</srccurr>     </srctime>     <srccitea>PP 1411-A</srccitea>     <srccontr>Contours of depth to top of Paleozoic rocks</srccontr>    </srcinfo>    <srcinfo>     <srccite>      <citeinfo>       <origin>Huffman, A. Curtis, Jr; Condon, Steven M.</origin>       <pubdate>1993</pubdate>       <title>Stratigraphy, structure, and paleogeography of Pennsylvanian and Permian rocks, San Juan Basin and adjacent areas, Utah, Colorado, Arizona, and New Mexico</title>       <geoform>Digital and/or Hardcopy Resources</geoform>       <pubinfo>        <pubplace>Reston, VA</pubplace>        <publish>U.S. Geological Survey</publish>       </pubinfo>       <onlink>http://pubs.usgs.gov/bul/1808o/plate-18/pdf</onlink>      </citeinfo>     </srccite>     <typesrc>Digital and/or Hardcopy Resources</typesrc>     <srctime>      <timeinfo>       <sngdate>        <caldate>1993</caldate>       </sngdate>      </timeinfo>      <srccurr>publication date</srccurr>     </srctime>     <srccitea>Bulletin 1808-O, Plate 18</srccitea>     <srccontr>Contours of the altitude of the top of Permain rocks in the San Juan Basin area</srccontr>    </srcinfo>    <procstep>     <procdesc>Development of the data set by the agency/individuals identified in the 'Originator' element in the Identification Info section of the record.</procdesc>     <procdate>Unknown</procdate>    </procstep>    <procstep>     <procdesc>Development of structural surface from contours of PP1411A Plate 3. Included digitizing contours from Plate 3, then creating raster using ArcMap Topo-to-Raster tool, which was then contoured and edited to better fit the area.</procdesc>     <procdate>20120501</procdate>    </procstep>    <procstep>     <procdesc>Generating depth to Paleozoic rocks for San Juan Basin area. Included digitizing altitude contours from Bulletin 1808-O, Figure 18, creating a raster from the contours with ArcMap Topo-to-Raster tool, and subtracting those altitude values from the land-surface raster to create a depth raster. The depth raster was filtered to produce smoother contours with the ArcMap Filter tool. The filtered raster was contoured to produce 1000-ft contours, which were edited to omit outcrop conflicts.</procdesc>     <procdate>2013</procdate>    </procstep>    <procstep>     <procdesc>For the NARGFM region, the altitude of layer 1 (in feet) was subtracted from land surface to produce a depth to Permian rocks raster that was contoured and edited.</procdesc>     <procdate>2013</procdate>    </procstep>    <procstep>     <procdesc>The three contour files described above were merged, and used as input to generate a raster using the ArcMap Topo-to-Raster tool.</procdesc>     <procdate>2013</procdate>    </procstep>    <procstep>     <procdesc>Outcrop areas and areas of negative depth to top were replaced with zero values using index grids and raster calculator for a corrected depth to the Paleozoic and older rocks.</procdesc>     <procdate>2013</procdate>    </procstep>    <procstep>     <procdesc>The values of the final, merged raster of depth-to-top values were subtracted from the land-surface grid to produce the top of the Paleozoic rock raster.</procdesc>     <procdate>2013</procdate>    </procstep>    <procstep>     <procdesc>Created ASCII file of raster using Esri "Raster to ASCII" tool</procdesc>     <procdate>2014</procdate>    </procstep>   </lineage>  </dataqual>  <spdoinfo>   <direct>Raster</direct>   <rastinfo>    <rasttype>Grid Cell</rasttype>    <rowcount>997</rowcount>    <colcount>577</colcount>    <vrtcount>1</vrtcount>   </rastinfo>  </spdoinfo>  <spref>   <horizsys>    <planar>     <gridsys>      <gridsysn>Universal Transverse Mercator</gridsysn>      <utm>       <utmzone>12</utmzone>       <transmer>        <sfctrmer>0.9996</sfctrmer>        <longcm>-111.0</longcm>        <latprjo>0.0</latprjo>        <feast>500000.0</feast>        <fnorth>0.0</fnorth>       </transmer>      </utm>     </gridsys>     <planci>      <plance>row and column</plance>      <coordrep>       <absres>1000.0</absres>       <ordres>1000.0</ordres>      </coordrep>      <plandu>Meter</plandu>     </planci>    </planar>    <geodetic>     <horizdn>D_North_American_1983</horizdn>     <ellips>GRS_1980</ellips>     <semiaxis>6378137.0</semiaxis>     <denflat>298.257222101</denflat>    </geodetic>   </horizsys>  </spref>  <eainfo>   <detailed>    <enttyp>     <enttypl>Attribute Table</enttypl>     <enttypd>Table containing attribute information associated with the data set.</enttypd>     <enttypds>Producer defined</enttypds>    </enttyp>    <attr>     <attrlabl>Value</attrlabl>     <attrdef>Altitude of top of Paleozoic rocks in the Upper Colorado River Basin study area</attrdef>     <attrdefs>Producer defined</attrdefs>     <attrdomv>      <rdom>       <rdommin>-21428.65625</rdommin>       <rdommax>13484.7451171875</rdommax>       <attrunit>Feet</attrunit>      </rdom>     </attrdomv>    </attr>   </detailed>   <overview>    <eaover>The top of the Paleozoic rocks layer was created from contour maps of the depth to the top of Paleozoic rocks in the UCRB from PP1411A Plate 3, contours of the altitude of the top of Permian rocks in the San Juan Basin area from Bulletin 1808-O figure 18, and from NARGFM top of model layer 1 (top of Kaibab limestone).</eaover>    <eadetcit>Geology of Paleozoic Rocks in the Upper Colorado River Basin in Arizona, Colorado, New Mexico, Utah, and Wyoming, Excluding the San Juan Basin, 2003, Geldon, Arthur L., USGS Professional Paper: 1411-A, Plate 3 and  Stratigraphy, structure, and paleogeography of Pennsylvanian and Permian rocks, San Juan Basin and adjacent areas, Utah, Colorado, Arizona, and New Mexico, 1993; Huffman, A. Curtis, Jr., Condon, Steven M. USGS Bulletin: 1808-O, Figure 18.</eadetcit>   </overview>  </eainfo>  <distinfo>   <distrib>    <cntinfo>     <cntorgp>      <cntorg>U.S. Geological Survey</cntorg>     </cntorgp>     <cntpos>Ask USGS -- Water Webserver Team</cntpos>     <cntaddr>      <addrtype>mailing address</addrtype>      <address>445 National Center</address>      <city>Reston</city>      <state>VA</state>      <postal>20192</postal>      <country>USA</country>     </cntaddr>     <cntvoice>1-888-275-8747 (1-888-ASK-USGS)</cntvoice>     <cntemail>http://water.usgs.gov/user_feedback_form.html</cntemail>    </cntinfo>   </distrib>   <distliab>Although this data set has been used by the U.S. Geological Survey, U.S. Department of the Interior, no warranty expressed or implied is made by the U.S. Geological Survey as to the accuracy of the data and related materials.
